case_info.court: Supreme Court of the United States
case_info.question_presented: Whether IEEPA authorizes the President to impose tariffs

petitioner.name: Learning Resources, Inc. and hand2mind, Inc.
petitioner.description: Family-owned educational toy companies challenging IEEPA tariffs

respondent.name: Donald J. Trump, President of the United States, et al.
respondent.description: Federal government defending IEEPA tariff authority

supporting_respondent.name: States of Oregon, Arizona, Colorado, Connecticut, Delaware, Illinois, Maine, Minnesota, Nevada, New Mexico, New York, Vermont

spaeth_codes_reference.note: IEEPA (50 U.S.C. 1701-1707) was enacted as Title II of Public Law 95-223 (1977), which also amended TWEA in Title I. The Spaeth database code 376 ('Trading with the Enemy Act, as amended') covers both TWEA and IEEPA.

secondary_legal_provisions.description: Article II, Section 2 (commander-in-chief) - foreign affairs/national security
Executive Order - tariffs implemented via presidential proclamations/EOs

legal_issues.description: Whether 'regulate importation' in IEEPA Section 1702(a)(1)(B) includes the power to impose tariffs

legal_issues.description: Whether IEEPA unconstitutionally delegates legislative taxing power to the President without sufficient standards

legal_issues.description: Whether reading tariff power into 'regulate exportation' would violate the Export Clause prohibition on export taxes
legal_issues.spaeth_issue_description: executive authority vis-a-vis congress or the states

arguments.summary: Congress has never used the word 'regulate' alone to authorize taxation or tariffs. When Congress delegates tariff power, it always uses explicit terms like 'duty,' 'tariff,' or 'tax.'
arguments.detail: The word 'regulate' appears approximately 1,499 times in the U.S. Code, but never to authorize taxation or revenue-raising. When Congress intends to permit tariffs, it explicitly uses terms like 'duty,' 'tariff,' 'tax,' or 'import surcharge.' Title 19 contains numerous examples of explicit tariff delegations with substantive and temporal limits. The ordinary meaning of 'regulate' is to 'control by rule' or 'subject to restrictions,' not to impose monetary exactions.

spaeth_codes.issue_description: executive authority vis-a-vis congress or the states
spaeth_codes.provision_description: Trading with the Enemy Act, as amended

evidence.description: Section 122 of Trade Act uses 'duties' explicitly, limited to 15% for 150 days
Section 301 authorizes 'duties or other import restrictions' with explicit procedural requirements
Chief Justice Marshall distinguished taxing power from commerce power
Contemporary dictionary defines 'regulate' as 'control by rule' or 'subject to restrictions'
evidence.citation: The Concise Oxford Dictionary of Current English 943 (6th ed. 1976)

arguments.summary: Reading tariff power into 'regulate exportation' would be unconstitutional because the Constitution prohibits export taxes, proving 'regulate' cannot mean 'tax.'
arguments.detail: IEEPA gives the President power to 'regulate importation or exportation.' If 'regulate' includes power to tax, IEEPA would unconstitutionally authorize export taxes in violation of Article I, Section 9, Clause 5. The word 'regulate' cannot be a 'chameleon' meaning one thing for imports and another for exports. The Government offers no coherent response to this structural problem.

spaeth_codes.issue_description: executive authority vis-a-vis congress or the states
spaeth_codes.provision_description: Article I, Section 9, Paragraph 5 (export clause)

evidence.description: Export Clause prohibits taxes on exports
evidence.citation: U.S. Const. art. I, Section 9, cl. 5

evidence.description: IEEPA authorizes regulation of both 'importation or exportation'
Single use of statutory phrase must have fixed meaning
evidence.citation: Cochise Consultancy, Inc. v. United States ex rel. Hunt, 587 U.S. 262, 268 (2019)

relevant_cases.case_name: Cochise Consultancy, Inc. v. United States ex rel. Hunt
relevant_cases.relevance: Single statutory phrase must have consistent meaning

arguments.summary: No President in IEEPA's nearly 50-year history has ever invoked it to impose tariffs, demonstrating settled understanding that IEEPA does not authorize tariffs.
arguments.detail: Despite being the 'most frequently cited emergency authority' with 69 invocations since 1977, no President until now has claimed IEEPA authorizes tariffs. Prior Presidents have used IEEPA for asset freezes, financial sanctions, embargoes, and travel restrictions - but never tariffs. This consistent practice informs interpretation of statutory scope.

spaeth_codes.issue_description: executive authority vis-a-vis congress or the states
spaeth_codes.provision_description: Trading with the Enemy Act, as amended

evidence.description: No President in 50 years invoked IEEPA for tariffs
Agency's longstanding practice can inform statutory interpretation
evidence.citation: Loper Bright Enters. v. Raimondo, 603 U.S. 369, 386 (2024)

evidence.description: President Trump previously used Section 232 and 301 for tariffs, not IEEPA

arguments.summary: None of the eight other verbs surrounding 'regulate' in Section 1702(a)(1)(B) involves revenue-raising, confirming Congress did not intend to delegate taxing power.
arguments.detail: The verbs in IEEPA Section 1702(a)(1)(B) are: 'investigate,' 'block,' 'regulate,' 'direct and compel,' 'nullify,' 'void,' 'prevent,' and 'prohibit.' Under noscitur a sociis, words are known by their companions. None of these verbs involves taxation or revenue-raising. This confirms Congress did not bury taxing power in 'regulate.'

spaeth_codes.issue_description: executive authority vis-a-vis congress or the states
spaeth_codes.provision_description: Trading with the Enemy Act, as amended

evidence.description: The complete list of verbs in Section 1702(a)(1)(B)
Noscitur a sociis principle - word known by company it keeps

relevant_cases.case_name: Yates v. United States
relevant_cases.relevance: Noscitur a sociis - word known by company it keeps

arguments.summary: The Major Questions Doctrine applies because the claimed tariff authority represents an unprecedented assertion of power with extraordinary economic and political significance.
arguments.detail: The IEEPA tariffs constitute the largest peacetime tax increase in American history - over $3 trillion in projected revenue over 10 years. They increased the effective tariff rate tenfold to the highest in over a century. Congress does not hide such vast economic power in vague statutory language. The lack of historical precedent plus the breadth of claimed authority indicates the tariffs exceed legitimate reach.

spaeth_codes.issue_description: executive authority vis-a-vis congress or the states
spaeth_codes.provision_description: Article I, Section 1 (delegation of powers)

evidence.description: Lack of historical precedent plus breadth of claimed authority indicates exceeded reach
Major questions require clear congressional authorization
CBO projects $3.3 trillion in tariff revenue over 10 years

arguments.summary: Title 19's detailed tariff architecture with specific limits would be rendered meaningless if IEEPA authorized unlimited tariffs with no constraints.
arguments.detail: Congress has created an elaborate system of tariff statutes in Title 19, each with careful substantive, procedural, and temporal limits. Section 122 limits tariffs to 15% for 150 days. Section 201 requires ITC findings and caps rate increases at 50%. If IEEPA authorized unlimited tariffs, these carefully crafted limitations would be superfluous and easily circumvented.

spaeth_codes.issue_description: executive authority vis-a-vis congress or the states
spaeth_codes.provision_description: Infrequently litigated statutes

evidence.description: Section 122 limits: 15% maximum, 150 days duration
Section 201 requires ITC finding and caps rate at 50% above existing

arguments.summary: Congress enacted IEEPA specifically to LIMIT presidential emergency powers, not to grant unlimited authority to reshape the global economy.
arguments.detail: IEEPA was enacted in 1977 after Congress studied abuses of TWEA emergency powers. The legislative history shows Congress was concerned about 'open-endedness' of TWEA. Congress added procedural constraints, triggering conditions, and exceptions. It would be anomalous to interpret a statute designed to constrain as granting unprecedented, unlimited tariff authority.

spaeth_codes.issue_description: executive authority vis-a-vis congress or the states
spaeth_codes.provision_description: Trading with the Enemy Act, as amended

evidence.description: House Report showing concern about TWEA's open-endedness
IEEPA added enumerated exceptions not in TWEA

arguments.summary: The district court properly exercised jurisdiction because IEEPA is not a 'law providing for tariffs' and the CIT's exclusive jurisdiction does not apply.
arguments.detail: CIT jurisdiction under 28 U.S.C. Section 1581(i)(1) applies only to actions 'arising out of any law of the United States providing for tariffs.' This case arises out of IEEPA, which does not provide for tariffs. The executive orders lack 'authority of law' and thus are not 'laws providing for tariffs.' The district court's jurisdiction analysis was correct.

arguments.summary: The phrase 'regulate importation' plainly includes tariffs because tariffs are a traditional, commonplace method of regulating imports since the Founding.
arguments.detail: The ordinary meaning of 'regulate' encompasses controlling and adjusting by rule. Since the Founding, tariffs have been recognized as a quintessential way to regulate trade. Chief Justice Marshall, James Madison, and Justice Story all recognized that regulating commerce includes imposing duties. McGoldrick v. Gulf Oil held that 'laying a duty on imports is also an exercise of the power to regulate foreign commerce.'

spaeth_codes.provision_description: Article I, Section 8, Paragraph 3 (interstate commerce clause)

evidence.description: Laying duty on imports is exercise of power to regulate foreign commerce
evidence.citation: McGoldrick v. Gulf Oil Corp., 309 U.S. 414, 428 (1940)

evidence.description: Power to regulate commerce not controverted even by imposition of duties
Justice Story: 'No one can doubt that power to regulate trade involves power to tax it'
evidence.citation: 2 Joseph Story, Commentaries on the Constitution Section 1076 (1833)

evidence.description: Regulate means 'to fix, establish or control; to adjust by rule'

arguments.summary: Congress ratified the interpretation that 'regulate importation' includes tariffs when it reenacted TWEA language in IEEPA after the Yoshida decision upheld Nixon's tariffs.
arguments.detail: President Nixon imposed tariffs under TWEA in 1971, which were upheld in Yoshida (1975). Congress was aware of this when it enacted IEEPA in 1977, reenacting the same 'regulate importation' language. When Congress adopts language from an earlier act, courts presume Congress adopted the construction given to that language. The House Report specifically cited Yoshida.

spaeth_codes.provision_description: Trading with the Enemy Act, as amended

arguments.summary: Algonquin held that 'adjust imports' includes license fees (monetary exactions), making 'regulate importation' - a broader phrase - an even clearer case for including tariffs.
arguments.detail: In Algonquin, the Court held that a statute authorizing the President 'to adjust imports' encompassed not just quotas but also 'monetary methods' like license fees. Since 'regulate importation' is broader than 'adjust imports,' the authority to impose tariffs follows a fortiori. The Court rejected the argument that Congress must use consistently explicit, well-defined language when delegating tariff authority.

arguments.summary: The Major Questions Doctrine is inapplicable in the foreign affairs context where the President has inherent Article II authority and Congress deliberately grants broad emergency powers.
arguments.detail: The Court has never applied MQD in the foreign affairs context. One would expect Congress to confer major powers on the President to address major international crises - that is a natural, common-sense expectation. The President has inherent Article II foreign affairs authority, and IEEPA adds congressional authorization on top of that. Under Youngstown Zone 1, the President's actions receive the strongest presumption of validity.

arguments.summary: Regulatory tariffs on foreign commerce are distinct from domestic revenue-raising taxes; tariffs regulate trade, not raise revenue as their primary purpose.
arguments.detail: The tariffs here are regulatory, not revenue-raising. The power exercised is the foreign commerce power, not the taxing power. Tariffs would be most effective if no one ever paid them - their purpose is to regulate behavior, not generate revenue. The taxing power is distinct from the commerce power; tariffs may be imposed under either but serve different functions.

spaeth_codes.provision_description: Article I, Section 8, Paragraph 1 (taxing, spending, general welfare, or uniformity clause)

evidence.citation: Board of Trustees v. United States, 289 U.S. 48, 58 (1933)

evidence.description: Court rejected state's argument that tariffs are necessarily an exertion of taxing power

arguments.summary: Plaintiffs concede IEEPA authorizes quotas, which are economically equivalent to tariffs; it makes no sense to allow quotas but not tariffs.
arguments.detail: Plaintiffs admit that 'regulate importation' includes quotas on imported goods. As Algonquin illustrates, quotas and tariffs are substantively equivalent - both affect price and quantity of foreign imports. Plaintiffs never explain why Congress would authorize quotas to cap quantities but not tariffs, which can achieve similar results. Indeed, some tariffs here are 'so high as to effectively prevent importation' - showing tariffs can be equivalent to prohibitions, which IEEPA expressly authorizes.

spaeth_codes.issue_description: executive authority vis-a-vis congress or the states
spaeth_codes.provision_description: Trading with the Enemy Act, as amended

arguments.summary: The nondelegation doctrine has little or no force in foreign affairs where the President has inherent Article II authority and Congress may delegate broadly.
arguments.detail: This Court has repeatedly held that strict limitations on domestic delegations do not apply in foreign affairs. Congress must 'paint with a broader brush' given unpredictable foreign contingencies. The President is the constitutional actor in foreign affairs and Congress supplements, not creates, his authority. IEEPA provides adequate standards through its emergency declaration requirements, time limits, exceptions, and congressional oversight.

relevant_cases.case_name: UNITED STATES v. ARTHREX INC.
relevant_cases.relevance: Arthrex - appointments clause; executive control

arguments.summary: The CIT has exclusive jurisdiction because presidential modifications to the Harmonized Tariff Schedule are 'law of the United States' providing for tariffs.
arguments.detail: Under 19 U.S.C. Section 3004(c)(1)(C), presidential modifications to the HTSUS 'shall be considered to be statutory provisions of law for all purposes.' Plaintiffs' claims arise out of those modifications - they seek to declare them unlawful, enjoin their enforcement, and set them aside. This falls squarely within the CIT's exclusive jurisdiction under Section 1581(i)(1).

spaeth_codes.issue_description: judicial administration: jurisdiction or authority of federal district courts or territorial courts
spaeth_codes.provision_description: Infrequently litigated statutes

evidence.description: Presidential HTSUS modifications considered statutory provisions of law
CIT exclusive jurisdiction over civil actions arising out of tariff laws

relevant_cases.case_name: K MART CORPORATION v. CARTIER, INC., et al.
relevant_cases.relevance: K Mart v. Cartier - gray market goods; district court jurisdiction
relevant_cases.justice_votes_note: Case from 1988 predates all current justices

arguments.summary: The President's determinations that trade deficits and drug trafficking constitute 'unusual and extraordinary threats' warranting emergency action are essentially unreviewable.
arguments.detail: IEEPA requires the President to find an 'unusual and extraordinary threat' to national security, foreign policy, or economy. These determinations involve foreign policy and national security judgments that courts are ill-equipped to second-guess. The President's threat assessments receive substantial deference. Congress provided political oversight through reporting requirements and termination power, not judicial review.

spaeth_codes.issue_description: judicial review of administrative agency's or administrative official's actions and procedures
spaeth_codes.provision_description: Article II, Section 1 (executive power)

evidence.description: Courts defer to executive determinations in immigration/national security context
Executive determinations not subject to judicial review

relevant_cases.case_name: Trump v. Hawaii
relevant_cases.relevance: Deference to executive in immigration/national security context

arguments.summary: Tariffs 'deal with' the declared emergencies as leverage to bring trading partners to negotiate, consistent with IEEPA's purpose and prior presidential practice.
arguments.detail: IEEPA requires the President to use powers to 'deal with' the declared threat. The trafficking tariffs deal with the fentanyl crisis by pressuring China, Canada, and Mexico to take enforcement action. The trade tariffs have brought 75+ trading partners to negotiate, resulting in framework agreements worth trillions. President Nixon used tariffs similarly - as leverage to achieve the Smithsonian Agreement addressing balance-of-payments crisis.

spaeth_codes.issue_description: executive authority vis-a-vis congress or the states
spaeth_codes.provision_description: Trading with the Enemy Act, as amended

evidence.description: More than 75 trading partners approached US to negotiate after tariffs
US announced trade deals with EU, Indonesia, Philippines, Vietnam, Japan, South Korea, UK
Nixon tariffs used as leverage, leading to Smithsonian Agreement in 5 months

relevant_cases.case_name: United States v. Yoshida Int'l, Inc.
relevant_cases.relevance: Nixon tariffs under TWEA upheld; 'regulate importation' includes tariffs
relevant_cases.justice_votes_note: Federal Circuit case (CCPA 1975), not in SCOTUS database

spaeth_codes.issue_description: executive authority vis-a-vis congress or the states
spaeth_codes.provision_description: Article II, Section 1 (executive power)

oral_argument_exchanges.question: Why doesn't the major questions doctrine apply to the President in this case?
oral_argument_exchanges.response: In foreign affairs context, where President has inherent Article II authority, it's natural to expect Congress to confer major powers to address major international crises. This is Justice Jackson's Youngstown framework - broad powers subject to ongoing political oversight.
oral_argument_exchanges.key_quote: One would expect Congress to confer major powers on the President to address major international crises.

spaeth_codes.issue_description: executive authority vis-a-vis congress or the states
spaeth_codes.provision_description: Article I, Section 8, Paragraph 3 (interstate commerce clause)

oral_argument_exchanges.question: What exactly are the Article II powers you're relying on? Tariffs are quintessential Article I powers - power to tax, regulate foreign commerce.
oral_argument_exchanges.response: We have two layers - bedrock of President's inherent Article II foreign affairs powers, plus sweeping congressional delegation. We're not asserting taxing power; these are regulatory tariffs under foreign commerce power.
oral_argument_exchanges.key_quote: We don't contend that what's being exercised here is the power to tax. It's the power to regulate foreign commerce. These are regulatory tariffs.

spaeth_codes.issue_description: executive authority vis-a-vis congress or the states
spaeth_codes.provision_description: Trading with the Enemy Act, as amended

oral_argument_exchanges.question: How is a quota equivalent to revenue-raising? A quota sets a limit but doesn't generate revenue. Why when Congress intended regulate to mean taxing, it used taxes simultaneously?
oral_argument_exchanges.response: In Algonquin, the Court held 'adjust imports' includes monetary methods like license fees without using word 'tariffs.' Congress is not bound to specific words when delegating tariff authority.
oral_argument_exchanges.key_quote: The phrase 'adjust imports' was held to include monetary methods despite not mentioning tariffs.

spaeth_codes.issue_description: executive authority vis-a-vis congress or the states
spaeth_codes.provision_description: Trading with the Enemy Act, as amended

oral_argument_exchanges.question: IEEPA was designed to limit presidential authority. Congress was concerned about TWEA abuses. How can we interpret a constraining statute as granting unlimited authority?
oral_argument_exchanges.response: Congress changed triggering conditions and procedures but kept the same operative language including 'regulate importation.' Natural inference is Congress did not intend to change scope of tools available.
oral_argument_exchanges.key_quote: Congress took the language from TWEA and enacted the very same phrase 'regulate importation' in IEEPA.

spaeth_codes.issue_description: executive authority vis-a-vis congress or the states
spaeth_codes.provision_description: Trading with the Enemy Act, as amended

oral_argument_exchanges.question: What's the significance of the Nixon example and precedent here? What was the scope of the Nixon tariffs?
oral_argument_exchanges.response: Nixon imposed 10% tariff across the board to address balance-of-payments deficit. Used as leverage to bring trading partners to negotiate - achieved Smithsonian Agreement in 5 months. Upheld by Federal Circuit predecessor under 'regulate importation.' Two years later, Congress reenacted same phrase in IEEPA.
oral_argument_exchanges.key_quote: The tariff there was used as here, in part as leverage to get our trading partners to the negotiating table.

spaeth_codes.issue_description: executive authority vis-a-vis congress or the states
spaeth_codes.provision_description: Trading with the Enemy Act, as amended

oral_argument_exchanges.question: Can you point to any other statute where 'regulate importation' has been used to confer tariff-imposing authority?
oral_argument_exchanges.response: TWEA as interpreted in Yoshida, and the related 'adjust imports' in Section 232. We also rely on historical sources showing long pedigree of foreign commerce power delegations including tariffs.
oral_argument_exchanges.key_quote: The only two statutes are TWEA as interpreted in Yoshida and the closely related 'adjust imports' in Section 232.

spaeth_codes.issue_description: executive authority vis-a-vis congress or the states
spaeth_codes.provision_description: Trading with the Enemy Act, as amended

oral_argument_exchanges.question: [To petitioner's counsel] Walk us through the 50-year history of IEEPA non-use for tariffs.
oral_argument_exchanges.response: IEEPA has been invoked 69 times - for asset freezes, embargoes, sanctions, travel restrictions. Never once for tariffs. No President until now claimed this authority. This consistent practice informs statutory meaning.
oral_argument_exchanges.key_quote: 69 invocations of IEEPA and not once did any President claim tariff authority until now.

spaeth_codes.issue_description: executive authority vis-a-vis congress or the states
spaeth_codes.provision_description: Article I, Section 1 (delegation of powers)

oral_argument_exchanges.question: On nondelegation - how does IEEPA provide sufficient intelligible principle if it grants unlimited tariff authority?
oral_argument_exchanges.response: IEEPA provides standards: must deal with unusual and extraordinary threat, must address national security/economy, subject to congressional oversight and reporting, default one-year limit on emergencies. This Court has upheld broader delegations in foreign affairs.
oral_argument_exchanges.key_quote: Congress retained robust political oversight over the President's exercise of emergency powers.
